questions.question: An elevon is:
options: an all moving tailplane that has no elevator.
the correct name for a V-tail.
a surface that extends into the airflow from the upper surface of the wing to reduce the lift.
a combined aileron and elevator fitted to an aircraft that does not have a conventional horizontal stabilizer (tailplane).
questions.explanation: On tailless configurations the elevon performs both elevator and aileron duties.

questions.question: When rolling at a steady rate the:
options: up-going wing experiences an increase in effective angle of attack.
rate of roll depends only on aileron deflection.
down-going wing experiences an increase in effective angle of attack.
effective angle of attack of the up-going and down-going wings are equal.
questions.explanation: The down-going wing sees a higher local angle of attack, generating extra lift for the roll.

questions.question: The control surface which gives longitudinal control is:
options: the rudder.
the ailerons.
the elevators.
the flaps.
questions.explanation: Elevators (or stabilators) control pitch about the lateral axis.

questions.question: Ailerons give:
options: lateral control about the lateral axis.
longitudinal control about the lateral axis.
lateral control about the longitudinal axis.
directional control about the normal axis.
questions.explanation: Ailerons control roll (lateral control) about the longitudinal axis.

questions.question: Aileron reversal would be most likely to occur:
options: with a rigid wing at high speed.
with a flexible wing at high speed.
with a rigid wing at low speed.
with a flexible wing at low speed.
questions.explanation: At high dynamic pressure a flexible wing can twist opposite to the commanded deflection, reversing roll response.

questions.question: If the ailerons are deflected to 10°, compared to 5° this will cause:
options: an increased angle of bank.
an increased rate of roll.
no change to either bank angle or roll rate.
a reduction in the adverse yawing moment.
questions.explanation: Larger deflection produces greater rolling moment, increasing roll rate.

questions.question: Yawing is a rotation around:
options: the normal axis controlled by elevator.
the lateral axis controlled by rudder.
the longitudinal axis controlled by ailerons.
the normal axis controlled by rudder.
questions.explanation: Yaw is rotation about the vertical (normal) axis controlled by the rudder.

questions.question: If the control column is moved forward and to the left:
options: the left aileron moves up, right aileron moves down, elevator moves up.
the left aileron moves down, right aileron moves up, elevator moves down.
the left aileron moves up, right aileron moves down, elevator moves down.
the left aileron moves down, right aileron moves up, elevator moves up.
questions.explanation: Forward stick lowers the elevator; left stick raises the left aileron and lowers the right.

questions.question: The secondary effect of yawing to port is to:
options: roll to starboard.
pitch nose-up.
roll first to starboard and then to port.
roll to port.
questions.explanation: Weathercock stability plus differential lift produces a roll in the same direction as the yaw.

questions.question: Due to the aerodynamic centre of the fin being above the longitudinal axis, if the rudder is moved to the right, the force acting on the fin will give:
options: a yawing moment to the left but no rolling moment.
a rolling moment to the left.
a rolling moment to the right.
a yawing moment to the right but no rolling moment.
questions.explanation: A side force above the centreline creates a rolling moment opposite to the rudder deflection.

questions.question: What should be the feel on a 'full and free' check of the controls?
options: A gradual stiffening of the controls.
Rebound on reaching the stops.
A solid stop.
Controls should not be moved to the stops.
questions.explanation: A proper check feels smooth travel ending at a positive stop without rebound.

questions.question: The purpose of control locks on a flying control system is:
options: to enable any free movement in the control system to be detected.
to prevent structural damage to the controls in gusty conditions when the aircraft is on the ground.
to keep the control surface rigid to permit ground handling.
as a security measure.
questions.explanation: Locking prevents gust loads from slamming the surfaces while parked.

questions.question: An irreversible control:
options: may be moved by operating the cockpit control but not by the aerodynamic loads acting on the control surface.
has less movement in one direction than the other.
may be moved either by the cockpit control or by a load on the control surface.
is when the control locks are engaged.
questions.explanation: Hydraulic power controls often incorporate irreversible gearing preventing feedback to the cockpit.

questions.question: Ailerons may be rigged slightly down (drooped):
options: to increase the feel in the control circuit.
to correct for adverse aileron yaw.
to allow for up-float in flight to bring the aileron into the streamlined position.
to give a higher CLMAX for take-off.
questions.explanation: Rigging them slightly low lets airflow lift them into neutral during flight.

questions.question: The tailplane shown has inverted camber. To cause the aircraft to pitch nose-up:
options: the control column must be pushed forward.
the control column must be pulled backwards.
the control wheel must be rotated.
the incidence of the tailplane must be decreased because the negative camber will make it effective in the reverse sense.
questions.explanation: Pulling back increases tailplane lift (more download) pitching the nose up.

questions.question: If an aileron is moved downward:
options: the stalling angle of that wing is increased.
the stalling angle of that wing is decreased.
the stalling angle is not affected but the stalling speed is decreased.
the wing twist is reduced.
questions.explanation: Down aileron raises local angle of attack, so stall occurs sooner (lower stall angle).

questions.question: When rudder is used to give a coordinated turn to the left:
options: the left pedal is moved forward, and the rudder moves right.
the right pedal is moved forward and the rudder moves left.
the left pedal is moved forward and the rudder moves left.
both pedals move aft.
questions.explanation: Pressing the left pedal deflects the rudder left to yaw the aircraft into the turn.

questions.question: The higher speed of the upper wing in a steady banked turn causes it to have more lift than the lower wing. This may be compensated for by:
options: use of the rudder control.
operating the ailerons slightly in the opposite sense once the correct angle of bank has been reached.
increasing the nose-up pitch by using the elevators.
reducing power.
questions.explanation: Opposite aileron (aileron into the turn) counters the rolling tendency due to speed differential.

questions.question: The purpose of a differential aileron control is to:
options: give a yawing moment which opposes the turn.
reduce the yawing moment which opposes the turn.
give a pitching moment to prevent the nose from dropping in the turn.
improve the rate of roll.
questions.explanation: Differential up deflection reduces adverse yaw by lowering drag on the down-going wing.

questions.question: When displacing the ailerons from the neutral position:
options: the up-going aileron causes an increase in induced drag.
the down-going aileron causes an increase in induced drag.
both cause an increase in induced drag.
induced drag remains the same, the up-going aileron causes a smaller increase in profile drag than the down-going aileron.
questions.explanation: The down-going aileron increases lift and therefore induced drag on that wing.

questions.question: The purpose of aerodynamic balance on a flying control is:
options: to get the aircraft into balance.
to prevent flutter of the flying control.
to reduce the control load to zero.
to make the control easier to move.
questions.explanation: Aerodynamic balance reduces pilot effort by offsetting hinge moments.

questions.question: A horn balance on a control surface is:
options: an arm projecting upward from the control surface to which the control cables are attached.
a projection of the outer edge of the control surface forward of the hinge line.
a rod projecting forward from the control surface with a weight on the end.
a projection of the leading edge of the control surface below the wing undersurface.
questions.explanation: A horn balance extends the surface ahead of the hinge to provide aerodynamic balancing.

questions.question: An aileron could be balanced aerodynamically by:
options: making the up aileron move through a larger angle than the down aileron.
attaching a weight to the control surface forward of the hinge.
having the control hinge set back behind the control surface leading edge.
having springs in the control circuit to assist movement.
questions.explanation: Setting the hinge aft places part of the surface ahead of the hinge, giving aerodynamic balance.

questions.question: Control overbalance results in:
options: a sudden increase in stick force.
a sudden reduction then reversal of stick force.
a sudden loss of effectiveness of the controls.
a gradual increase in stick force with increasing IAS.
questions.explanation: Overbalanced controls can pull themselves further deflected, reversing stick force direction.

questions.question: A control surface is mass balanced by:
options: fitting a balance tab.
attaching a weight acting forward of the hinge line.
attaching a weight acting on the hinge line.
attaching a weight acting behind the hinge line.
questions.explanation: Mass balance weights are placed ahead of the hinge to align the centre of gravity with the hinge axis.

questions.question: If the control wheel is turned to the right, a balance tab on the port aileron should:
options: move up relative to the aileron.
move down relative to the aileron.
not move unless the aileron trim wheel is turned.
move to the neutral position.
questions.explanation: Balance tabs deflect opposite to the control surface; with left aileron down, its balance tab goes up to assist movement.

questions.question: The purpose of an anti-balance tab is to:
options: trim the aircraft.
reduce the load required to move the controls at all speeds.
reduce the load required to move the controls at high speeds only.
give more feel to the controls.
questions.explanation: Anti-balance tabs move with the control surface to increase hinge moment, providing heavier feel.

questions.question: When the control column is pushed forward a balance tab on the elevator:
options: will move up relative to the control surface.
will move down relative to the control surface.
will only move if the trim wheel is operated.
moves to the neutral position.
questions.explanation: As the elevator trailing edge goes down, the balance tab moves up to reduce required control force.

questions.question: The purpose of a spring tab is:
options: to maintain a constant tension in the trim tab system.
to increase the feel in the control system.
to reduce the pilot's effort required to move the controls against high air loads.
to compensate for temperature changes in cable tension.
questions.explanation: Spring tabs only assist when hinge moments are high, reducing required pilot effort.

questions.question: The purpose of a trim tab is:
options: to assist the pilot in initiating movement of the controls.
to zero the load on the pilots controls in the flight attitude required.
to provide feel to the controls at high speed.
to increase the effectiveness of the controls.
questions.explanation: Trim tabs are adjusted to relieve control forces in steady flight conditions.

questions.question: To re-trim after failure of the right engine on a twin-engine aircraft:
options: the rudder trim tab will move right and the rudder left.
the trim tab will move left and the rudder right.
the trim tab will move left and the rudder remain neutral.
the trim tab will move right and the rudder remain neutral.
questions.explanation: To counter right yaw, rudder must deflect right; the trim tab moves opposite (left) to hold that deflection.

questions.question: To trim an aircraft which tends to fly nose heavy with hands off, the top of the elevator trim wheel should be:
options: moved forward to raise the nose and this would cause the elevator trim tab to move down, and the elevator to move up.
moved backwards to raise the nose, and this would cause the elevator trim tab to move down, and the elevator to move up.
moved backwards to raise the nose, and this would cause the elevator trim tab to move up, and the elevator to move up.
moved backwards to raise the nose, and this would cause the elevator trim tab to move up and cause the nose to rise.
questions.explanation: Rolling the trim wheel aft lowers the tab, forces the elevator up and raises the nose.

questions.question: To achieve the same degree of longitudinal trim, the trim drag from a variable incidence trimming tailplane would be:
options: greater than that from an elevator.
the same as that from an elevator.
less than that from an elevator.
zero regardless of trim position.
questions.explanation: Adjusting tailplane incidence produces less trim drag than holding elevator deflection.

questions.question: Following re-trimming for straight and level flight because of forward CG movement:
options: nose-up pitch authority will be reduced.
nose-down pitch authority will be reduced.
longitudinal stability will be reduced.
tailplane down load will be reduced.
questions.explanation: With a forward CG more elevator up deflection is already used, leaving less nose-up authority.

questions.question: An aircraft has a tendency to fly right wing low with hands off. It is trimmed with a tab on the left aileron. The trim tab will:
options: move up, causing the left aileron to move up and right aileron to move down.
move down, causing the left aileron to move down and right aileron to move up.
move up, causing the left aileron to move down and the right aileron to move up.
move down, causing both ailerons to move toward neutral.
questions.explanation: To raise the right wing the left aileron must come up; its trim tab deflects opposite (up relative to the surface) to hold the aileron up.
